sourceDesc.p: This prosopography has been populated from the letters of Dinah Craik. Information about each person comes from Craik's correspondence and the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

person.note: Karen Bourrier is an assistant professor at the University of Calgary. Her interests include Victorian studies, disability studies, and the digital humanities.
Janice Parker is a PhD candidate at the University of Calgary.
Kailey Fukushima is a Digitization Assistant at the University of Calgary. She holds a BA (Hons) in English, 2016.
Aaron Ellsworth is an MA student at the University of Calgary. His research interests include comics, semiology, and narratology.
Jaclyn Carter is a PhD candidate at the University of Calgary.
Sidney Cunningham is an MA student at the University of Calgary. His specialization is in contemporary transgender literature, as well as early modern literature.
Keila Karinne Aleman is a PhD candidate and teaching assistant at the University of Calgary. Her research is on gender in popular culture, comics, and manga.
Pippa Ruddy is a Master's student at the University of Calgary. Her interests include affect theory, performance/performativity studies, and intersectional feminism.
Rahman Zainub is an MA student at the University of Calgary.
Kerry-Leigh Fox is an MA student at the University of Calgary. Her interests include Victorian literature, Vernon Lee, queer studies, gender studies, and creative writing.
Christopher was one of Dinah's cats from her time at Wildwood.
Blackie was the Craiks' cat at the Corner House.
Pixie was the Craiks' horse at the Corner House.
Songbird was a horse of Dinah Craik's at the Corner House.
Nell was Thomas Mulock Jr.'s beloved horse.
Ophelia was one of Dinah's chickens at Lynover Cottage. She was a Cochin hen given to Dinah as a present.
Hamlet was one of Dinah's chickens at Lynover Cottage. He was a Cochin chicken given to given to Dinah as a present, and was the male companion to Ophelia.

event.label: Marriage
event.desc: Dinah Maria Mulock married George Lillie Craik.

person.note: Henry Alden was an editor at Harper's magazine.
John Phayre was a clerk at Harper's. See https://archive.org/stream/houseofharpercen00harp/houseofharpercen00harp_djvu.txt
Mrs. Edward Caird was married to the Master of Balliol, Dr. Caird. See http://archive.spectator.co.uk/article/3rd-june-1916/15/the-late-mrs-edward-caird
James Ripley Osgood was the editor of the Atlantic and possibly Our Young Folks.
Sampson Low was the London literary agent and correspondent for the American publisher Harper's.
Tom Mulock was Dinah's younger brother.
Thomas Mulock was Dinah's father.
Dinah (Mellard) Mulock was Dinah (Mulock) Craik's mother
Ben Mulock was Dinah's youngest brother.
Jane Mulock was one of Dinah's paternal aunts who lived in Bath.
Emily Mulock was one of Dinah's paternal aunts who lived in Bath.
Eliza Mulock was the eldest of Dinah's paternal aunts living at Bath.
Fanny Mulock was one of Dinah's paternal aunts living at Bath.
Fanny Mulock was one of Dinah's paternal aunts living at Bath.
Alicia Mulock was one of Dinah's paternal aunts who lived in Bath. She married Francis Parker Hoblyn, a surgeon, in 1864.
Mary Reade was Dinah's maternal aunt.
Samuel Carter Hall was the editor of New Monthly Magazine and the Art Journal. He married Anna Maria Fielding in 1824.

event.label: Marriage
event.desc: Anna Maria Fielding married Samuel Carter Hall.

person.note: Anna Maria Hall was an Irish-born writer and editor. She lived in England with her husband Samuel Carter Hall.
Annie Miers was a close friend of Dinah's who attended her wedding to George and who, along with Emily Wolley, was one of the two executors of Dinah's estate.
Ellen, an English subject born in Brazil, was the niece of Annie Miers and a young friend of Dinah's. Dinah attended her wedding to Archibald Grey MacGregor on 24 September 1887.
Edward, an English subject born in Brazil, was the nephew of Dinah's close friend Annie Miers. Edward's father was Francis Miers.
Harry, an English subject born in Brazil, was the nephew of Dinah's close friend Annie Miers. Harry's father was Francis Miers.
Katie, an English subject born in Brazil, was the niece of Dinah's close friend Annie Miers. Katie's father was Francis Miers. She married Edward Sydney Fry in Bromley in 1886.
Annie, an English subject born in Brazil, was the niece of Dinah's close friend Annie Miers. Annie's father was Francis Miers.
Julia was the niece of Dinah's close friend Annie Miers. Julia's father was Francis Miers.
Felicia Jennings was a friend Annie Miers and companion to Annie's brother Francis's mother-in-law for many years after she was widowed.
Westland Marston was a playwright. Dinah was very close to their entire family throughout the 1850s and beyond, often spending Christmas with them. Ben may have been engaged to one of the girls.
Eleanor Marston was married to Westland Marston. ODNB.
Philip Marston was the third child of Dinah's close friends John Westland Marston and Eleanor Marston. Dinah Craik was his godmother. ODNB.
Maria James was a friend of Dinah's from her days in Camden.
Elizabeth Gaskell was a novelist and acquaintance of Dinah Craik's.
Clarence Dobell and his wife Emilywere close friends of Dinah's. Clarence illustrated Dinah's 1860 collection Our Year and painted a portrait of Dinah.
Emily was the wife of Clarence Dobell. Her sister married Henry Craik.
Walter Dobell was the son of Clarence and Emily Dobell
Eva was the young daughter of Dinah's good friends Clarence and Emily Dobell and the niece of poet Sydney Dobell. Eva also became a poet and is known for her WWI poetry.

event.label: Marriage
event.desc: Mary Alice Dobell married Briton Riviere.

event.label: Marriage
event.desc: Mary Alice Dobell married Briton Riviere.

person.note: Julietta Dobell was the matriarch of the Dobell clan. Ursula March in Craik's novel John Halifax, Gentleman may have been based on her.
J. Miriam Benn, "Drysdale George (1824-1904)," ODNB.
Dinah knew Macready in her youth from her time in London. According to Aleyn Lyell Reade her father got into a huge fight with Macready.
Fanny (Waugh) Hunt was William Holman Hunt's first wife.

Edith Waugh was William Holman Hunt's second wife and the sister of his first wife Fanny Waugh. Dinah Craik chaperoned her to Switzerland for her marriage to Holman Hunt in 1875 when the Deceased Wife's Sister Act made such a marriage illegal.
Dinah's goddaughter and the first child of Edith Waugh and Holman Hunt
Alexander Macmillan was the younger of the Macmillan brothers.

Daniel Macmillan was the elder of the Macmillan brothers, who established a small bookshop and publishing house at 57 Aldersgate Streetin 1842. He died of tuberculosis, leaving the company and his family to his brother Alexander.
Dinah translated works by François Guizot and his daughter Henriette Guizot de Witt.
Dinah translated works by Henriette Guizot de Witt and her father François Guizot.
Laura Herford, the first woman to be admitted to the Royal Academy, was a close friend of Dinah Craik's. She was aunt to the illustrator Helen Allingham.
Artist Helen Allingham illustrated Craik's work. She was niece to the artist Laura Herford.
Miss Fanny was a servant in the Craiks' first household as a married couple, Upper Tooting. See Letter to Miss Rankin in the Parrish Collection, Princeton.
George Craik was Dinah's husband.
Henry Craik was George's younger brother. He married Emily Dobell (née Duffield)'s sister.
William Craik was George's younger brother.
Reverend James Craik was the father of Dinah's husband George. ODNB.
Margaret Craik was Dinah's mother-in-law.
Jane Craik was George's older sister.
Maggie Craik was George's older sister.
Janie Craik was the wife of George's younger brother William.
Georgiana Craik was a cousin of Dinah's husband, who Dinah knew well beforehand. She was born in Brompton, London, but lived in Ireland.

George Lillie Craik was the author of The New Zealanders, which Dinah read as a child. He was the father of Georgiana Craik and the uncle of Dinah's husband, also George Lillie Craik. He took up a post in Ireland.
Dorothy Craik was Dinah's adopted daughter.
Alexander Pilkington was the first husband of Dinah's daughter Dorothy. The pair married in 1887.
Frederick Noel-Paton was the son of the Craik's good friends the Noel-Patons.
Mona Paton was the eldest daughter of Noel and Margaret Paton. She had a difficult adolescence, and came to stay with the Craik's every spring for several years.

Jack Kidston was husband to Mona Paton, and Vicar of Hampton Poyle, near Oxford. Initially the couple was very happy but the marriage struggled when Mona became a Theosophist, though the two remained married.
Caroline Aimlie Cross, called Dolly, was the daughter of the Craiks' good friends the Noel-Patons.
Lora Paton was the daughter of the Craiks' good friends the Noel-Patons.
Olive Cockerell lived with the Craiks as a companion for Dorothy in the 1870s. Her brother was Sydney Cockerell and Octavia Hill was her godmother.
Sydney Cockerell, a book collector and museum curator, was a friend of Dinah's. He was brother to Olive. ODNB.

Sydney John Cockerell was Sydney Carlyle and Olive Cockerell's father.
ODNB.

Alice Elizabeth Cockerell was Sydney Carlyle and Olive Cockerell's mother.
ODNB.
Stewart Henderson, misnamed by Dinah in a letter as "Stewart Anderson," was an acquaintance of Dinah's. Stewart was in a secret relationship with Carmela Meo.
Leonora Braham was a Soprano famous for several Gilbert and Sullivan roles, mentored by Craik, who tried to get her out of acting.
Frederick Barnes was the husband of Lily Barnes, who committed suicide.
Miss Rankin was a friend of Dinah's from Wemyss Bay. A directory lists a Miss Rankin of Rothesay in 1857.
Miss Nair appears to be a friend of Dinah's from Wemyss Bay.
Boyd ppears to be a friend of Craik's from Wemyss Bay, and an organist.
Andrew Thomson was a professor and friend of Dinah's from Wemyss Bay.
Davidson appears to be a friend of Craik's from Wemyss Bay.
Annie was a domestic servant who followed the Craiks from Glasgow to England, only to be married back in Glasgow soon after.
Miss Oxland was Dorothy and Olive's governess.
Arnold, an acquaintance at Dinah's Mulock Aunt's house in Bath, appears to have been married to Gertrude.
Gertrude, an acquaintance at Craik's Mulock Aunt's house in Bath, appears to be married to Arnold.
Holland was an acquaintance of the Craiks, possibly a neighbour at the Corner House.
Smith was an acquaintance of the Craiks, possibly a neighbour at the Corner House.
Ned Bewley was a young acquaintance of the Craiks. He was a distant relative of Dinah's and the son of Sir Edmund Thomas Bewley (1807–1908), who wrote the book "The Family of Mulock."
May Bewley was a young acquaintance of the Craiks and the daughter of Sir Edmund Thomas Bewley (1807–1908), who wrote the book "The Family of Mulock."
Orrinsmith was an acquaintance of the Craiks, possibly a neighbour at the Corner House.

John Orrin Smith was an English wood-engraver. He, along with his business partner W. J. Linton, was one of the principal engravers for the Illustrated London News from 1836 to his death in 1843. During this time period, he changed his surname from Orrin Smith to Orrinsmith.
ODNB.
James Payn was a novelist and editor of the Cornhill Magazine from 1883 to 1896.

Carmela Meo was a young Italian girl whom Dinah met in 1885. She took up a subscription among her friends to have her placed at the Royal College of Music. The relationship ended poorly two years later when Carmela determined to marry a young man Dinah found unsuitable.
Luigi Meo, a violinist and older brother of Carmela, was an acquaintance of Dinah's. He married widow Jemima Henderson in 1884; Jemima's son Stewart was in a secret relationship with Carmela.
Reverend Wolley was the Vicar of Shortlands Vicarage, Bromley, Kent. He and his wife were close friends of the Craiks
Mrs. Wolley was the wife of Reverend Wolley and a close friend of the Craiks.
Henry Lewes was an acquaintance of Dinah's while she lived in the Corner House

Mary Constance Pike was a young person and friend of Dinah's during her years at the Corner House. She was the eldest sister of Bel and Ada. Connstance Pike married Charles Thomas in 1891 and had two daughters, Constance Dinah and Margaret Isabel.
Ada Pike was a young person and friend of Dinah's during her years at the Corner House. Youngest sister of ConnieBel
Bel Pike was a young person and friend of Dinah's during her years at the Corner House. She was the middle sister of ConnieAda Pike.
Mrs. Bradway was a seamstress who worked for the Craiks in the 1880s.
Miss Grubb seems to be the Craiks hatmaker in the 1880s.
Miss Eastlake was a popular English actress and a leading lady in Wilson Barrett's company. She started her own theater company, which went bankrupt.

Wilson Barrett was an actor and playwright whom Dinah Craik struck up a correspondence with late in life. Barrett and Miss Eastlake performed in Lord Lytton's classical drama Junius, or the Household Gods, at the Princess's Theatre, London, in February 1886.
Lord Alfred Tennyson was a popular English poet.
Hallam Tennyson was Lord Alfred Tennyson's son, named for his friend Arthur Hallam.

person.affiliation: Partner in publishing company Cundall & Addey.
person.note: Mr. Addey was a publisher of children's literature. Dinah Craik published "A Hero" with Addey & Co and also wrote for Addey & Co's children's periodical The Charm.

person.affiliation: Partner in publishing company Chapman and Hall
person.note: Edward Chapman founded Chapman and Hall with William Hall and worked with the company until his retirement in 1864.

person.affiliation: Partner in publishing company Cundall & Addey.
person.note: Mr. Cundall was a successful photographer and a publisher of children's literature.

person.affiliation: Partner in publishing company Chapman and Hall
person.note: William Hall founded Chapman and Hall with Edward Chapman and worked with the company until his sudden death in 1847.
Thomas Kibble Hervey was a poet, critic, and journalist who contributed to and later edited the popular periodical the Athenaeum.
Mary Howitt was a popular Victorian writer who published both independently and collaboratively with her husband William Howitt.
William Howitt was a popular Victorian writer who published both independently and collaboratively with his wife Mary Howitt.
Mrs. Morris was a skilled embroiderer who bound some of Dinah Craik's books. She was a model and muse for both her husband William Morris, and Dante Gabriel Rosetti.
William Morris was a British poet, novelist, and textile designer.
Mrs. Morris was an acquaintance of Dinah Craik's in the early 1850s.
Mrs. Chisholm was an acquaintance of Dinah Craik's in the early 1850s.
Mrs. Oliphant was a best-selling Victorian novelist and a life long friend of Dinah Craik's.
Allan Park Paton was best known for editing the Hamnet Shakespeare, published between 1877 and 1879. He worked at the Greenock Library, Watt Monument.
Dante Gabriel Rossetti was a famous poet and a painter of the Pre-Rafaelite brotherhood.
Miss Adams was a composer. She delivered a song to Dinah by mail sometime between 1859 and 1865.
Mrs. Brougham was a friend of George and Dinah Craik's.
Pen Browning was the son of Robert Browning and Elizabeth Barrett Browning ODNB.

Reverend Dr. Thomas Chalmers served as the leader of the Church of Scotland and later established the Free Church of Scotland. He was an important and well-known religious figure in the nineteenth century. ODNB.
Miss Chalmers was a friend of George and Dinah Craik's, and niece to the Reverend Dr. Thomas Chalmers.
Elizabeth Rundle Charles was a popular Victorian poet and novelist. She lived with her husband in Hampstead from 1851 until her death in 1896. ODNB.

George Duplessis was a French curator and art historian who specialized in the art of engraving. An anonymous note on letter PU34 (AM20763) in the Princeton Parrish Collection suggests that Dinah Craik may have helped translate his text "The Wonders of Engraving."

Mrs. Field was an acquaintance of Dinah's who helped her to organize a glee club. Mrs. Field may have been Mrs. Julia Field, the owner and proprietor of the Catharine Lodge School for Young Ladies in Brompton, London.

Anna Maria Goldsmid was an important figure in the Anglo-Jewish community of the nineteenth century. She devoted most of her adult life to the improvement of Jewish medical and educational institutions in London. ODNB.
Mr. Harry appears to have be an early photographer who might have developed photographs of Dinah Craik.
Joseph Wesley Harper was a partner in the American publishing firm Harper & Brothers. Joseph Wesley was the third Harper brother and joined the firm in 1823.
Fletcher Harper was a partner in the American publishing firm Harper & Brothers. Fletcher was the youngest of the four Harper brothers and joined the firm in 1825.
Amelia Robertson Hill was Sir Joseph Noel Paton's sister. She is best-known for her work in sculpture, but began her career as a painter. Dinah Craik was one of her sitters c. 1844. ODNB.
David Octavius Hill was married to Amelia Robertson Hill (née Paton), a friend of Dinah Craik's. ODNB.
Jesus Christ is one of the central figures of Christianity.
Charles Kingsley was a Christian socialist, a university professor, and a celebrated novelist. He and Dinah Craik were literary acquaintances. ODNB.
Fanny Kingsley was wife to Charles Kingsley. She authored her husband's biography after his death in 1875. ODNB.

persName.note: Mrs. Longstaff was a friend of Dinah's from Edinburgh.

person.note: George William Lovell was a popular Victorian dramatist. He was an early acquaintance of Thomas Mulock's and a friend of Dinah Craik's. ODNB.
Maria Ann Lovell was an actress turned playwright. She and her husband George Lovell were friends with Dinah Craik and were also acquainted with her father, Thomas Mulock. ODNB.
Minna Lovell was a friend of Dinah's who lived with her at Lynover Cottage. She was briefly engaged to Dinah's brother Benjamin from around 1860 to 1863.
Cicely Marston was the first child of Dinah's close friends John Westland Marston and Eleanor Marston. ODNB.
Lord Robert Montagu was a Conservative politician and a religious controversialist. He was a professional acquaintance of Charles Kingsley's. ODNB.
Arthur O'Shaughnessy was married to Eleanor Marston, the youngest daughter of Dinah's close friends John Westland Marston and Eleanor Marston. ODNB.
Eleanor (Marston) O'Shaughnessy was the second child of Dinah's close friends John Westland Marston and Eleanor Marston. ODNB.

John William Parker was the owner and proprietor of the publishing firm John W. Parker & Son. John W. Parker & Son acquired Fraser's Magazine for Town and Country in 1847 and published some of Dinah Craik's earliest stories. ODNB.

John William Parker was an English publisher and the son in Parker & Son publishing. He joined his father's firm in 1843 and worked as the general manager until his death in 1860. Parker & Son published some of Dinah Craik's earliest stories. ODNB.
Miss Shirley wrote the lyrics to a piece of music that Dinah had in her possession c. 1859.
Mr. Harry Taylor was a tenor in Dinah Craik's glee club c.1862.
William Makepeace Thackeray was a popular Victorian writer best-known for his satirical novels, including Vanity Fair. ODNB.

Sir Michael Shaw Stewart was a British baronet and was a Member of Parliament for Renfrewshire, Scotland.
"Obituary: Sir Michael Shaw-Stewart," Times (London, UK), Dec. 11, 1903.

Lady Octavia Grosvenor was married to Sir Michael Shaw-Stewart. She was the granddaughter of George Leveson-Gower.
"Obituary: Sir Michael Shaw-Stewart," Times (London, UK), Dec. 11, 1903.

George Leveson-Gower was a wealthy and controversial Anglo-Scottish politician. He was the second Marquess of Stafford and the first Duke of Sutherland.
ODNB.

George Sutherland-Leveson-Gower was a Whig politician and the eldest son of the first Duke of Sutherland. He inherited his Earlship from his mother's side after her death in 1839.
ODNB.

Mr. Adderley, first Baron Norton, was the founder of the Saltley Reformatory— an industrial school in which Dinah's father Thomas Mulock took a great interest.
ODNB.
Mulock Thomas, "Notes re industrial schools: Saltley Reformatory printed Letter to the Earl of Lichfield," 1860-1894, D615/PL/6/26, Records of the Anson Family of Shugborough, Earls of Lichford; Staffordshire County Record Office, Stoke-on-Trent Archive Service.
Edward Bentley was a London publisher and the proprietor of Bentley & Co. ODNB.
George Bentley was the son of Richard Bentley. He became a partner in his father's publishing company in 1845 and later shared the business with his own son. ODNB.
Richard Bentley was the son of Edward Bentley. He was a well-known publisher in London throughout his lifetime. ODNB.
Robert Chambers was a partner in the publishing company W. & R. Chambers. Dinah often visited his residence at Doune Terrace in Edinburgh's Georgian New Town. ODNB.
William Chambers was a partner in the publishing company W. & R. Chambers. ODNB.
Clara was presumably one of Dinah's friends from her time at Wildwood. She accompanied Dinah on a journey to Glasgow sometime between 1861 and 1865.

Miss Coates was a cousin of Sydney Dobell's. She lived at Upper Terrace Lodge with her friend Miss Marian James.
"Donations for the Bow and Poplar Charity Organisation Committees," Reports of the Council and of the District Committees, (Charity Organisation Society, London, 1887): 22.
“David Gray’s First Proof-Sheet,” The Irish Monthly 15, (1887): 425.
James Hedderwick, ed., “Memoir of the Author,” Poems of David Gray, with Memoirs of His Life, (Boston: Roberts Brothers, 1865): 36-37.

Charles Dickens is English novelist who is still widely read and celebrated in the twenty-first century. He is known for his astute criticisms of Victorian social conditions in novels such as Bleak House. ODNB
Frederick William Fairholt was a successful artist and antiquary who regularly contributed to the Art Journal. ODNB.
William Josiah Irons was a Church of England clergyman. Dinah might have encountered him during his residency at St. Paul's Cathedral (1860 to 1870). ODNB.

Marian James was a friend of Dinah's and an acquaintance of the Dobell family. Miss James lodged at Upper Terrace Lodge, Hampstead with Miss Coates— a cousin of Sydney Dobell's.
“David Gray’s First Proof-Sheet,” The Irish Monthly 15, (1887): 425.
Elizabeth Cleghorn Gaskell, “List of Publications: Sampson Low, Son, and Co,” Right at Last, and Other Tales, (London: Sampson Low, Son & Co., 1860): 333.
"A History of West Down, Hindhead GU26 6BQ," Grayshott Village Archive, last modified February 6, 2012.
James Hedderwick, ed., “Memoir of the Author,” Poems of David Gray, with Memoirs of His Life, (Boston: Roberts Brothers, 1865): 36-37.
Marian James, A Lord of the Creation, (London: Groombridge & Sons, 1857): 1.
“Miss Marian Julia James, Deceased,” The London Gazette 28448, (20 December, 1910): 9500.
Samuel Halkett, ed., Dictionary of Anonymous and Pseudononymous English Literature 3, (New York: Haskell House, 1926-1934): 401. Web.

Mrs. Loudon was a writer specializing in botany and natural history. She was the first editor of the Ladies' Companion at Home and Abroad from 1849 to 1851, during which time she became well-known for her work on middle-class women’s publications. Dinah was well-aquainted with Mrs. Loudon when she was living at Camden Street in the 1840s.
Camilla [Toulmin] Newton Crosland, Landmarks of a Literary Life 1820–1892 (New York: Charles Scribner’s Sons, 1893), 134.
Laurel Brake and Marysa Demoor, eds. Dictionary of Nineteenth-century Journalism in Great Britain and Ireland (Gent: Academia P, 2009), 379–340.
ODNB.

Lützow was a Prussian soldier famous for leading the volunteer corps in the War of Liberation.
"Lützow, Adolf, Baron," The New International Encyclopædia, 1905.
William Shakespeare is widely regarded as the world's preeminent English dramatist. He is best known for his innovations in theatre and for his re-workings of the English sonnet. ODNB.

Mrs. Valentine, otherwise known by her maiden name Laura Jewry or her pseudonym Aunt Louisa, was a writer of children's fiction. Dinah introduced her to Chapman and Hall on behalf of her acquaintance Leitch Ritchie, c. 1851.
"Valentine, L. (Laura), 1814-1899," Library of Congress Name Authority File, accessed Aug. 1, 2015. http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n81149497.html
WM. H. Peet, "Laura Jewry, Afterwards Mrs. R. Valentine" Notes & Queries 11S-XII, (1915): 266.

Richard Waddington was an acquaintance of Dinah's who attended the University of Oxford from 1862 to 1867. According to Dinah, he was "a first rate German scholar" with an excellent work ethic.
Foster, Joseph, Alumni Oxoniensis: The Members of the University of Oxford 1715-1886 4 (1888): 1478.
Janet Wills (née Chambers) was the youngest sister of the publishing duo William and Robert Chambers. She married the successful journalist William Henry Wills in 1846. ODNB.
William Henry Wills was a successful journalist and journal editor. He was one of the original contributers to Punch and was an assistant editor for Chambers's Edinburgh Journal. ODNB
Anne Chambers was the first wife of the publisher Robert Chambers. ODNB.
Mary Chapman was married to the publisher Edward Chapman of Chapman and Hall. ODNB.

Mr. Guild was the proprietor of Rose Cottage in Amberley. Dinah lodged with the Guild family sometime in the mid 1850s. She wrote the first chapter of John Halifax, Gentleman, there.
Diana Wall, "People of the Past: Dinah Maria Craik (née Mulock) (1826-1827)," Stroud District Council, accessed Aug. 1, 2015.
Mrs. Guild was married to Mr. Guild, the proprietor of Rose Cottage.

Dinah and Jane Winnard Hooper were friends and fellow writers. Jane was cousin to the Craiks in Glasgow.
Charlotte Mitchell, Ellen Jordan and Helen Schinske, eds., "Jane Margaret (Winnard) Hooper," Letters of Charlotte Mary Yonge (1823-1901), accessed July 22, 2015. http://www.yongeletters.com/people?person=711
Charles Kean was a popular nineteenth-century actor and manager of London's Princess's Theatre from 1850-1859. He was best-known for his work in Victorian Shakespeare revivals. ODNB.
Mr. Lamont and his wife were friends of Dinah's. She met them while lodging with Allan Park Paton at Greenock in 1849.
Mrs. Lamont and her husband were friends of Dinah's. She met them while lodging with Allan Park Paton at Greenock in 1849.
Tom Lamont was one of Mr. and Mrs. Lamont's two sons.

Luigi Lanzi was a historian of classical and renaissance Italian art. Dinah appears to have been researching Lanzi and other art historians around 1846.
Shearjashub Spooner, A Biographical History of the Fine Arts II.— M to Z, (Philadelphia: George Gebbie, 1873). https://archive.org/details/abiographicalhi04spoogoog.
Sorensen, Lee "Lanzi, Luigi [Antonio] (Abate)," Dictionary of Art Historians, accessed Aug. 2, 2015. https://dictionaryofarthistorians.org/lanzil.htm.

Frances (Fanny) Martin was a lifelong friend of Dinah Craik's. They lodged together during the summer of 1850 after Ben Mulock left for Australia. Frances helped found the College of Women (1874-1967), which was renamed The Frances Martin College after her death. ODNB.
Frances Macmillan was married to the publisher, Daniel Macmillan. ODNB.
Caroline Macmillan was married to the publisher, Alexander Macmillan. ODNB.

Thomas Cautley Newby was a successful English publisher best-known for publishing the first works by Emily and Ann Brontë, Wuthering Heights and Agnes Grey.
ODNB.

William Somerville Orr was the head of the publishing company Wm. S. Orr & Co.
William Somerville Orr, Orr's Circle of the Sciences, (London: Wm. S. Orr & Co, 1854).

Matthew Pilkington was an Irish church minister and art historian. Dinah appears to have been researching Pilkington and other Art Historians around 1846.
Shearjashub Spooner, A Biographical History of the Fine Arts II.— M to Z, (Philadelphia: George Gebbie, 1873). https://archive.org/details/abiographicalhi04spoogoog.
Sorensen, Lee "Pilkington, Matthew," Dictionary of Art Historians, accessed Aug. 2, 2015. https://dictionaryofarthistorians.org/pilkingtonm.htm.

Bryan Waller Procter was a nineteenth-century poet and lawyer. He and his wife Anne Procter were well-known in London for their literary salons.
ODNB.
Anne Skepper Procter was married to the poet and lawyer Bryan Waller Procter. From 1843 onwards, she and her husband hosted lively parties and were well-known names in literary London. ODNB.

Georgio Vasari is a famous sixteenth-century art historian. Dinah appears to have been researching Vasari and other art historians around 1846.
Shearjashub Spooner, A Biographical History of the Fine Arts II.— M to Z, (Philadelphia: George Gebbie, 1873). https://archive.org/details/abiographicalhi04spoogoog.
Sorensen, Lee "Vasari, Georgio," Dictionary of Art Historians, accessed Aug. 2, 2015. https://dictionaryofarthistorians.org/vasarig.htm.

Charlotte Brontë is a celebrated novelist of the Victorian period, best known for her novel, Jane Eyre.
ODNB.
Harriet was the laundry maid at the Corner House. Source: 1871, 1881 Census of England.
Mrs. Dyason was the housekeeper that took care of Dinah's home in Dover.
Louisa Dyason was the daughter of Jane, the housekeeper in charge of Dinah's home in Dover.
Maude Dyason was the daughter of Jane, the housekeeper in charge of Dinah's home in Dover.
Maria Mulock was Dinah's paternal grandmother.
Robert Mulock was Dinah's paternal grandfather.
Major Fulford was the governor of the Stafford County Jail, where Thomas Mulock was imprisoned more than once in the 1850s and 1860s. Fulford was in attendance at Thomas Mulock's funeral in 1869.
William Reade was married to Dinah's maternal aunt Mary Reade.
Elizabeth was Dinah's cousin on the maternal side. Her parents were Mary (Mellard) Reade and William Reade.
Charlotte was one of Dinah's paternal aunts. She married George Newenham Wright.
George Newenham Wright was an Irish writer and clergyman who was married to Dinah's paternal aunt Charlotte.ODNB.
Octavia Hill was a housing and social reformer. She was Olive Cockerell's godmother. ODNB.
Gertrude was the young daughter of Dinah's friend Ellen Jolly.
Arnold was the young son of Dinah's friend Ellen Jolly.
Paul Jolly was a son of Dinah's friend Ellen Jolly.
Elenor was the daughter-in-law of Dinah's friend JollyEllen.
A physician on Arran. Dr. John A. Jamieson was appointed Medical Officer of Health for Arran in 1852. source: Campbell, Thorbjörn. Arran: A History. New York: Birlinn, 2013.
Dr. Francis Hoblyn was a general practitioner and surgeon in Bath who married Dinah's paternal aunt Alicia in 1864. Ancestry.

James Spencer-Bell, formerly James Bell, was a British politician and MP for Guildford from 1853 to 1857. He and his wife, Mary Ann Spencer, had homes at Marylebone and Fawe Park, Keswick. The Spencer-Bells were friends of the Craiks.
Mary Ann Spencer-Bell was the wife of James Spencer-Bell. The SpencerBell were friends of the Craiks.
Frederick Spencer-Bell was the son of Dinah's good friends the Spencer-Bells. Fred died in a boating accident in 1886. "The Times", Saturday, 11 September 1886.

George Lawrence Pilkington was Alexander's younger brother who went to Africa as a missionary in 1890 and is largely credited with the first translation of the Luganda Bible. Dinah's daughter Dorothy often travelled with George between Ireland and Shortlands. ODNB.
Mrs. Pilkington was the mother of Alexander.
Henry Pilkington was the father of Alexander.
Jemima was the wife of Luigi Meo, a musician acquaintance of Dinah's.
Charlton Speer, an acquaintance of the Craiks, was a professor of piano at the Royal Academy of Music.
Amy Speer, wife of Charlton, was an acquaintance of the Craiks.
Mary Eastlake was a British actress.
W.H. Kendal was an actor and theatre manager. ODNB.
Martha Elliott was a servant of Dinah's aunts in Bath.
Charlotte Mary Yonge was a novelist and the author of the Heir of Redclyffe. George Craik was her publisher at Macmillan's.
Mrs. Langrishe lived with her husband Richard, an architect, at Shamrock Lodge, Althone.
John Keene was the Craiks coachman and gardener at Corner House In the 1881 Census of England he is listed as living at the Stables at Corner House.

Ellen Keene was the wife of the Craiks coachman and gardener at Corner House, John Keene. In the 1881 Census of England, Ellen is listed as a visitor, with two of her children, at Dinah's home in Dover.
Arthur Langdale was the husband of Annie Langdale. The Langdales were friends of the Craiks.
Annie Langdale was the wife of Arthur Langdale. The Langdales were friends of the Craiks.
Lady Caroline was the daughter of George Legge, the 3rd Earl of Dartmouth.
Dr. Phillips was a homeopathic physician in Bromley, originally trained as an orthodox physician, who treated Dinah in the final months of her life.

Mrs. Gatty was an English writer of children's literature and natural history.
ODNB.

George Bell was an English publisher and bookseller. From the late 1860s until his death in 1890, he was known as an authority on English copyright.
ODNB.

James Russell Lowell was a New England poet, critic, and diplomat. Lowell was well-known both in English and American literary circles, and in the latter part of his life, he travelled frequently between the two nations.
ANB.

John Ruskin was an influential art and social critic. He is famous for his articulation of gendered "separate spheres" in Victorian society — a model which insists on "male leadership and female care."
ODNB.

Oscar Wilde was a famous writer of the late Victorian period. He was a central figure in the decadent/aesthetic movement in Victorian literature and is well-known today for works such as The Picture of Dorian Gray (1890) and The Importance of Being Earnest (1895).
ODNB.

Mr. Metcalf was a shipowner and an aquaintance of Thomas Mulock Jr.'s. Metcalf was the M.P. for Tynemouth, near North Shields where the Kate docked before sailing to Cromarty. -->
Aleyn Lyell Reade, "Dinah Mulock and her Father," Notes and Queries (Feb. 2, 1924): 79

Captain Thomas Taylor commanded the Kate – an A1 vessel which sailed from Newcastle to Cromarty and then to Quebec in 1846. Dinah's younger brother Thomas Jr. was articled on the Kate.
Lucille H. Campey, Fast Sailing and Copper-Bottomed: Aberdeen Sailing Ships and the Emigrant Scots They Carried to Canada, 1774-1855 (Toronto: Natural Heritage/Natural History Inc., 2002), 78.
Little Mary was one of Dinah's favoured housemaids at Wildwood.
George Springfield was a friend of Dinah and Ben Mulock's.
Mr White was an acquaintance of Dinah's who lived in Glasgow. His daughter, Miss White, seems to have been romantically involved with another of Dinah's friends named Mr. Springfield.
Mrs. Herford was likely the mother of Dinah's close friend, Laura Herford.
Ivan was a relative of Dinah's close friend, Laura Herford.
Mrs. Blackett was married to Henry Blackett of the publishing house, Hurst and Blackett.
Mrs Ziepel was the matriarch of the Ziepel family.

Frank E. Smedley was a friend of Dinah's. He was a novelist and was also editor for Sharpe's London Magazine.
ODNB.
Mrs. Smedley was married to Frank Smedley.

Thomas Hughes was a writer of children's novels. He was well-known for authoring the bestselling children's novel, Tom Brown's School Days (1857).
ODNB.

Frances Hughes was the wife of the English writer, Thomas Hughes. They married in 1847.
ODNB.
Mrs. Smith was Harvey Orrin Smith's mother.

persName.note: Mrs Richards was married to Mr Richards

person.note: Mrs Jack was married to William Jack
Joe Mayall was the second son of the renowned photographer, John Mayall. Ben Mulock worked for John and Joe Mayall at their studio in London, for about a year from 1858 to 1859.

John Mayall was a successful professional photographer specializing in portraiture and narrative photography. He became a prominent name in England following his work at the Great Exhibition in 1851, and was commissioned to photograph the royal family on several occasions.
William Isbister was part of the publishing Daldy, Isbister and Co. He founded the publishing company with Alexander Strahan.
Jane Benson was a lifelong friend and colleague of Dinah's good friend Frances Martin.
Charles Blacker Vignoles was an influential railway engineer who Ben worked with on the Bahia and San Francisco Railway in Brazil. ODNB

Benjamin Waugh was a social reformer devoted to protecting the rights of children. He was editor of The Sunday Magazine, a religious periodical in which Dinah published articles, from 1874 to 1896. ODNB
Annie Adams Fields was an American writer married to James Fields. Gollin, Rita K. Annie Adams Fields: Woman of Letters. University of Massachusetts Press, 2002.
James Thomas Fields was an American writer and publisher with Ticknor & Fields. He was married to Annie Fields. American National Biography Online.
Leitch Ritchie was a Scottish novelist and journalist. ODNB. Ancestry.

Ouida was a popular late-Victorian novelist whose work often featured adultery and continental settings. She is best known for her novel Under Two Flags. Dinah compared the moral tone of her work unfavourably to her own.
Alexander Strahan founded Good Words, a journal which Dinah often published in.

person.occupation: Minister of the Church of Scotland
person.note: Rev. Dr. Donald Macleod took over as editor of Good Words after the death of his older brother Norman Macleod.

person.occupation: Minister of the Church of Scotland
person.note: Rev. Dr. Norman Macleod was editor of Good Words from its inception in 1860 until his death in 1872, when his brother Donald Macleod became editor of the magazine. ODNB.
Thomas Corbett was a Glasgowmerchant also known as a philanthropist who founded many Cooking Depots.
Archibald Corbett was the son of Thomas Corbett. He also knew Alexander Anderson and they travelled in Europe together. Archibald became a politician later in life.

Alexander Anderson was a poet who wrote under the pseudonym Surfaceman. When he was younger, in 1862, he became a platelayer for the Glasgow and South-Western Railway Company when Dinah recommended him to William Isbister as she felt he was talented and should move to literary work.

Elizabeth Meade was a children's writer and novelist who wrote as L.T. Meade, and is best known as a writer for older girls. Some of her work also appeared in Sunday Magazine, a publication Dinah also wrote for.

David Masson was a biographer as well as an editor with the publishing firm Macmillan & Co. Dinah corresponded with him while working as a copy-editor for Macmillan.
ODNB.
Jack M. Downs, "David Masson, Belles Lettres, and a Victorian Theory of the Novel," Victorian Literature and Culture 43 (2015): 1-21, doi:10.1017/S106015031400031X.

William Blake was an engraver and poet of the Romantic era. His work gained popularity with Victorian audiences following the publication of Alexander Gilchrist's Life of William Blake in 1863.
ODNB.

Alexander Gilchrist was a Victorian biographer best known for writing the first biography of William Blake. The Life of William Blake was published in 1863 after Gilchrist's death.
ODNB.
Reverend Richard S.C. Chermside was a novelist whose works Dinah reviewed for publication by Macmillan c. 1860.
Mrs Emily Chermside was married to the novelist Richard S.C. Chermside

George Cupples was a Scottish writer who specialized in nautical novels. Dinah reviewed his novel Herbert's Prize for publication by Macmillan.
"George Cupples Author Information," The Circulating Library: a Database of Victorian Fiction, 1837-1901, Web.
"The Author of 'the Green Hand'," Book News: an Illustrated Magazine of Literature and Books volume 9 (1890-1891): 452-453, Web.
Allan Cunningham was a Romantic poet and songwriter. Dinah advised Alexander Gilchrist to cut a section about Cunningham and his publishing relationships from the biography of William Blake.

Peter Bayne was a Scottish journalist who, from 1860 to 1862, also worked as the editor of The Dial.
ODNB.
Robert Cromeck was an engraver, editor, and art dealer who worked closely with William Blake.

Helen Brodie was a friend of Dinah Craik's. She was an amateur painter married to the sculptor William Brodie. The Brodies and their children lived in Aberdeen, Scotland.
"Brodie, William (1815–1881), ODNB.
Ancestry.

Mr. Brodie was married to Dinah's friend, Helen. He was a talented sculptor and a member of the Royal Scottish Academy. Dinah's husband George seems to have admired William and his works, as he included Brodie's name and image in a scrapbook of notable British artists and writers from the 1860s.
ODNB.
"Scrapbook," TypPh 805.63.3035, Houghton Library, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA.

William Chisholm was the father of Dinah's friend, Helen Brodie.
Ancestry.

Maggie Oliphant was Margaret Oliphant's first child.
Margaret Oliphant, "Margaret Oliphant: A Brief Chronology," Autobiography of Margaret Oliphant, ed. Elisabeth Jay (Broadview P, 2002), 25-26.

Lady Augusta Stanley was lady-in-waiting to Princess Victoria of Saxe-Coburg-Saalfeld and later served Queen Victoria first as a bedchamber woman, then as a secretary, then as a secretary to the royal children. She remained in the palace until her marriage in 1863 but remained close with the Queen for the rest of her life.
ODNB.

Hester Jane Austin was a distant cousin of Dinah's on her father's side. Her father was Thomas Homan-Mulock. She was also a poet.
Edmund Bewley, The Family of Mulock (Dublin: Privately Printed, 1905), 22-24.

Mrs. Barry was the wife of Sir Francis Tress Barry, a wealthy merchant. The Barrys were friends of the Craiks, and lived in Beckenham at the Clock House in 1872 before moving to a mansion in Clewer sometime before 1876.

Sir Francis Tress Barry was a wealthy English merchant who, along with his wife Sarah, were friends with the Craiks. The Barrys lived in Beckenham at the Clock House in 1872 before moving to a mansion in Clewer sometime before 1876.
James Newlands was a Scottish engineer and architect who Ben worked with in Liverpool.

Christopher Gayleard was a physician from Jamaica who was educated in England and was surgeon for the Bahia railway. He and Ben became friend when Ben worked on the Bahia Railway. Dr. Gayleard was with Ben in Swansea during the last few months of Ben's life, and visited Dinah in the 1880s.

Albert was a friend of Dinah's. He married Clara Dobell, sister of Clarence Dobell, a close friend of Dinah's. Albert wrote non-fiction pieces under his own name, and used the pseudonym A. J. Barrowcliffe to publish three novels. Sutherland, John. The Longman Companion to Victorian fiction. Routledge, 2014.

Grey Mott was the younger brother of Dinah's friend Albert Mott, sister of Clarence Dobell, a close friend of Dinah's. Albert wrote non-fiction pieces under his own name, and used the pseudonym A. J. Barrowcliffe to publish three novels. Sutherland, John. The Longman Companion to Victorian fiction. Routledge, 2014.
Captain Atkinson died in battle in Burma.
Allen Thomson was a well-known Scottish anatomist, embryologist, and professor.
Henry Burr Barnes was editor of the Interantional Review from 1874 to 1879, and a partner in his father's A. S. Barnes publishing firm.
F. R. Daldy was a publisher who was part of Daldy, Isbister and Co.

Frederick Macmillan was a son of Daniel and Frances Macmillan. He worked at the Macmillan's Cambridge branch with his cousin Robert Bowes before moving to the New York branch in 1871. In 1876 he returned to London to become a partner in the firm.
ODNB.

Robert Bowes was a nephew of Daniel and Alexander Macmillan's. He worked for Macmillan's London branch at Henrietta Street Macmillan & Co. from 1846 until 1863 and then moved to manage the Cambridge location.
ODNB.

Christina Rossetti was a poet who published in Macmillan's Magazine. She is well-known for her poem Goblin Market published in 1862. She was the sister of Dante Gabriel Rossetti and had connections with the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood.

Henry Kingsley was a novelist and essayist, who tried to seek a fortune in the Australian goldfields, but returned to England after little financial success and turned to writing.Charles Kingsley was his brother.
Mary Vidal was a novelist who was especially known for her Australian fiction, as she lived for some time in Australia. One of her more well-known works was Bengala, or, Some Time Ago.
Alexander Smith was a poet and essayist who wrote for publications such as Macmillan's Magazine and Good Words.

Elizabeth Gilbert was a campaigner for blind people, as she herself was blinded at a young age due to a severe case of scarlet fever. She supported many organziations that helped the blind, and also founded what became the Association for Promoting the General Welfare of the Blind.
"Mrs. Baleson of John's" is mentioned as an acquaintance of Dinah's who lives in Cambridge.
Mrs. Dickinson seems to have been a fan of Dinah's. She had a missing son.
Hungerford is a possibly fictional Captain written about by another writer whose initials were DMM.
Richard Garnett was a British librarian and author. He helped Dinah with her work on fairy tales.
H.G. Jebb was the author of Out of the Depths.
Edwyn Martin was a daily tutor. He was quite ill, and asked Dinah for a loan in 1859.
Charles Edward Mudie was the founder of a circulating library, which by the mid-century had over 25,000 subscribers. It became one of the major distributors of fiction in Britain.

Charles Perrault worked as a secretary at Academy of Inscriptions and Belles-Lettres and held many other positions. Perrault is best known for his writing in the fairy tale genre; his works include "Le Petit Chaperon Rouge" (Little Red Riding Hood"), "La Belle au bois dormant" (Sleeping Beauty), and "Cendrillon" (Cinderella).

Janet Wilson was sister to Daniel and Alexander Macmillan. She was a housekeeper for Alexander in 1833 and for Daniel in 1840, but had to return to Scotland both times for financial reasons. By July 1850, Janet was married to a Mr. Wilson and lived in Stewarton, Scotland.
Charles L. Graves, Life and Letters of Alexander Macmillan (Macmillan and Co), 44-60.

Dinah Backhouse was a friend of Dinah's who lived in the Lakes District. She was born in Rydal, Westmorland and married John Backhouse.
Ancestry.
DMC Diary, September 4 – 10, 1887 (Works 21), Dinah Maria Mulock Craik Collection, Harry Ransom Center, University of Texas at Austin.

Horace Harral was a wood engraver, etcher, and photographer who produced numerous pieces for the Illustrated London News. He was a pupil of John Orrinsmith and later formed a business partnership with Harvey Orrinsmith and W.J. Linton. Harral travelled to Australia with Ben Mulock in the 1850s.
NPG.
Gregory R. Suriano, The British Pre-Raphaelite Illustrators: A History of their Published Prings (Oak Knoll P, 2005), 21–22, Web.

Alfred Harral was a wood engraver and etcher for the Illustrated London News. He went gold-digging in Australia with Ben Mulock in the 1850s.
NPG.
Mrs. Frances Harral was a family friend of the Mulocks. She was Horace and Alfred's mother.

W.J. Linton was a well-known nineteenth-century wood-engraver and poet. He was one of the main engravers for the Illustrated London News. Linton worked with both John and Harvey Orrinsmith as well as Horace Harral.
Hans Christian Andersen was a Danish author and playwright known for popularizing fairy tales such as The Snow Queen, The Little Mermaid, and The Ugly Duckling.
Hermann appears to have been a servant of Craik's at The Corner House.
Mrs. Dixon was an acquaintance of Dinah's, and she had a daughter named Alice, who may have been Dinah's goddaughter.

Luigi Bramieri was an Italian writer and biographer. Dinah translated his tale Sophia de Wolfenbuttel in 1845, and it became one of her first publications with Chambers.
Pino Fasano, "Bramieri, Luigi," Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani vol. 13 (1971) Web.

Eliza Leslie was the daughter of one of Thomas Mulock's friends. In 1842, Dinah wrote to a friend that Miss Leslie was a writer and "a talented girl."
Aleyn Lyell Reade, The Mellards & Their Descendants, Including the Bibbys of Liverpool, with Memoirs of Dinah Maria Mulock & Thomas Mellard Reade (London: Arden P, 1915), 64.

Mrs Wilson seems to have been a family friend of Dinah's – likely on her mother's side. In the later years of her mother's illness, Dinah and her mother spent time in the Staffordshire countryside visiting Mrs. Wilson and the Parkers.
Mrs. Brunton was a friend of the Craiks at the Corner House. She was likely married to Dr. Brunton, who helped the Craiks euthanize Dorothy's sick dog in 1882.
Katie Keene was the daughter of the Craiks coachman and gardener at the Corner House, John Keene.

Camila Dufour Crosland was a writer and a good friend of Dinah's. They attended Jane Loudon's and Anna Maria Hall's literary soirées together during Dinah's early years in London. Dinah was her bridesmaid in 1848.
ODNB.

Miss Winnard was the sister of Jane Hooper, and cousin to Mary and Georgiana Craik (whom she also lived with). After Dinah's death, Miss Winnard provided Henry Craik with a note of remembrances. He passed that note along to Margaret Oliphant, and it formed the basis for her biography of Craik.
Andrew Lycett, Rudyard Kipling (Orion P, 2016) Web.

Henry James Townsend was trained as a surgeon but left medicine to become a painter of historical and literary subjects. Dinah became friends with Mr. Townsend and his family when she and her family lived in Brompton in the early 1840s. It was through Mr. Townsend that Dinah met her lifelong friend and mentor Anna Maria Hall.
Christopher Wood, The Dictionary of Victorian Painters (Woodbridge, England: Antique Collectors' Club, 1978), 487.

Leigh Hunt was an English essayist, poet, and literary critic. He was, for many years, the editor of the political newspaper the Examiner. However, he is best-known for being tried and imprisoned for libel against the Prince Regent in 1813. It seems that Dinah and George were close with Leigh Hunt and his family.
ODNB.

Augustus De Morgan was a mathemetician, historian, and a well-known professor at the University of London. He and his family lived in Hampstead Heath.
ODNB.
Marilyn Pemberton, "Influences, Inspirations, and Expectations," Out of the Shadows: The Life and Works of Mary De Morgan (Newcastle upon Tyne: Cambridge Scholars, 2012) 9-13, Web.

Sophia De Morgan was Professor Augustus De Morgan's wife. Sophia was a keen supporter of women's higher education and women's suffrage, campaigned on behalf of the poor, and supported the anti-slavery lobby. She wrote social tracts on these subjects, but was better known in the literary world for her works on nineteenth-century spiritualism such as "From Matter to Spirit."
ODNB.
Marilyn Marilyn Pemberton, "Influences, Inspirations, and Expectations," Out of the Shadows: The Life and Works of Mary De Morgan (Newcastle upon Tyne: Cambridge Scholars, 2012) 14-31, Web.

Alice De Morgan was the eldest child of Augustus and Sophia De Morgan. In 1853, at the age of 15, Alice died of a cold following a severe case of the measles.
Marilyn Marilyn Pemberton, "The Fifties and Sixties: Sisters, Dead and Live," Out of the Shadows: The Life and Works of Mary De Morgan (Newcastle upon Tyne: Cambridge Scholars, 2012) 32-46, Web.

Mrs. Hayden was the first American medium to work in England, beginning in 1852. She is widely credited for bringing spiritualism to Victorian England and was influential to emerging English writers such as Sophia De Morgan.
Ancestry.
"Hayden, Maria B. (ca. 1852)." Encyclopedia of Occultism and Parapsychology. Encyclopedia.com. (May 5, 2017).
Marilyn Marilyn Pemberton, "Influences, Inspirations, and Expectations," Out of the Shadows: The Life and Works of Mary De Morgan (Newcastle upon Tyne: Cambridge Scholars, 2012) 26-27, Web.

Dr. Samuel Brown was an apparent friend of Dinah's and a well known chemist. He also wrote and published scientific essays.
ODNB.
Helen Brown née Littlejohn was the wife and cousin of Dr. Samuel Brown.
Miss Lamb was an acquaintance of Dinah's who brought the news of the birth of Dr. Samuel Brown's daughter, Spring.

William Blackwood was in charge of the London office of Blackwood's Edinburgh Magazine, which he assumed full responsbility of in 1879.
ODNB.

John Blackwood, the uncle of William Blackwood, assumed control of Blackwoods publishing in 1852, and strengthened the firm's influence in the Victorian literary scene.
ODNB.

Charles Mayne Young was an English actor — best known for his performances as Hamlet — who acted in multiple theatres in London.
ODNB.

Anne Stanhope was countess of Chesterfield.
ODNB.

Sir Benjamin Ward Richardson extensively researched anaesthetics, and was greatly involved in public health. He also founded and edited the first journal dedicated to public health.
ODNB.

Walter Severn was well-known for his watercolour painting, including nature paintings and book illustration, though he lacked formal training. Dinah and Noel Paton both thought he was not a particularly strong artist.
ODNB.

John Keats, who gave up a medical career for a literary one, faced contemporary criticism and political attacks, and was only celebrated as a poet after his death.
ODNB.

Miss Blyth (pseud. May Beverley) was a writer who primarly produced literature for young people. Dinah read and reviewed her works when she was working as a publisher's reader for Macmillan Magazine c. 1860.
"Mary Popham Blyth: Author Information," Circulating Library, Web.

Dr. John Storrar was a close friend of Dinah's who worked as an M.D. and sat on the senate of the University of London. He stood in for her father and gave her away at her wedding in 1865.
Reade, The Mellards & Their Descendents, 88.
"Obituary," Annual Register of World Events: A Review of the Year 1886 vol. 128, ed. Edmund Burke (London: Rivingtons, 1887) 133, Web.

Miss Montgomery was a friend of Dinah's and Laura Herford's who lived at the Clock House in Hampstead Heath. Laura lived with her while attending the Royal Academy, and was one of the executors of her will.

James Braidwood was the superintendent of the London Fire Engine Establishment at the time of the Tooley Street Fire in 1861. Braidwood died in the fire after being crushed by debris. Among his mourners was Dinah's family friend, George Lovell.
"The Great Fire," Times (London), Tuesday, June 25, 1861, pg. 9; Issue 23968.
Mrs. Earl might have been a landlady or a housekeeper of Dinah's at Wildwood. She painted the exterior or Wildwood in 1861.
Spurgeon was a preacher whom Dinah's Mulock Aunts greatly admired.
Mrs. James was Marian James's mother.
Priestly Smith was Laura Herford's maternal cousin.
William Herford was the older brother of Dinah's friend Laura Herford.
Mrs. Reid was a long-time friend of Dinah's friend Fanny Martin.
Miss Bathurst was a friend of Mrs. Reid's who died suddenly in 1861. She was living in Belgium at the time of her death.

Sir James Young Simpson was a distinguished Scottish obstetrician. He is famous for being the first to discover the use chloroform as an anaesthetic in 1847. Dr. Simpson was apparently an old friend of Dr. Storrar's – the man who gave Dinah away at her wedding.
John Duns, ed., "Letters of Codolence," Memoir of Sir James Y. Simpson, Bart., M.D., (Edinburgh: Edmonston & Douglas, 1873) 535, Web.
Mrs. Janet Simpson was a friend of Dinah's acquaintance Mrs. Storrar. Both their husbands were doctors.
Lucy Storrar was married to Dinah's close friend, Dr. John Storrar. She and her family lived near Dinah for some time at Hampstead Heath.

Mary Elizabeth Laing was a friend of Dinah's and was married to Reverend David Laing. She and her family lived near Dinah when she lived at Hampstead Heath.
"Rev. David Laing," Legacies of British Slave-ownership database, UCL, http://wwwdepts-live.ucl.ac.uk/lbs/person/view/43565/.

Reverend David Laing was a Church of England Clergyman. He helped re-found and fund the Governesses' Benevolent Institution c. 1843 – an organization that Dinah contributed to with proceeds from her novel, Bread upon the Waters: A Governess's Life (1852).
"Rev. David Laing," Legacies of British Slave-ownership database, UCL, http://wwwdepts-live.ucl.ac.uk/lbs/person/view/43565/.
David Laing was the young son of Dinah's friend Mrs. Laing. His father, Reverend Laing, was also named David.

Mary Chambers was a daughter of Robert and Anne Chambers. She married a teaching doctor named Alexander McKenzie Edwards in 1856, and left behind three children when she died at the age of twenty-seven.
William Chambers, "His Last Days, Death, and Character," Memoir of Robert Chambers with Autobiographic Reminiscences of William Chambers (New York: Scribner, Armstrong, and Co., 1872) 307, Web.
"Letter from Lawson Tait to Charles Darwin, 1 March 1876," Correspondence of Charles Darwin vol. 24, supplement 1838–1875, eds. Frederick Burkhardt and James A. Secord (Cambridge P, 1876) 28, Web.

Mrs. Tomlinson and her husband Charles lived in Hampstead Heath and were acquaintances of Dinah's. They seem to have also known Minna, Marian, and the Ziepels. Sarah hosted Saturday evening parties which were frequented by scientists, writers, and artists, including Professor Augustus De Morgan and Margaret Oliphant.
Frederick Kurzer, "The Life and Work of Charles Tomlinson FRS: a Career in Victorian Science and Technology," Notes Rec. Royal Society of London 58.2(2004): 203–226, Web.
ODNB.

Mr. Tomlinson was an eminent experimental scientist and lecturer at King's College, London. Later in his life, he turned to literary subjects and became the first Dante lecturer at the University of London. Throughout his life, Mr. Tomlinson had a close relationship with the publisher, J. W. Parker. He and his wife lived in Hampstead from 1856 to 1866 and were friends with Dinah. It seems that he also knew her father and her aunts in some capactiy before that.
Frederick Kurzer, "The Life and Work of Charles Tomlinson FRS: a Career in Victorian Science and Technology," Notes Rec. Royal Society of London 58.2(2004): 203–226, Web.
ODNB.

John Joseph Griffin was a publisher as well as a well-known chemist and educator. He wrote and translated a Polytechnic Library series. John Joseph Griffin was a part proprietor of Richard Griffin & Co publishing alongside his brother Richard, but relinquished control to his nephew Charles Griffin in 1852.
ODNB.

Richard Griffin was a British publisher and co-founder of Richard Griffin & Co. publishing. The original company was founded in partnership with Thomas Tegg in 1820.
ODNB.

Charles Griffin was a British publisher and son of Richard Griffin. He was given his uncle's part of Richard Griffin & Co. in 1852.
ODNB.

Francis Sylvester Mahony was a satiric poet and journalist, and often wrote under the pseudonym Father Prout. He frequently published in Bentley's Miscellany.
ODNB.

Joseph Severn, father of Walter Severn, was a skilled artist best known for painting a deathbead portrait of his good friend John Keats. He received a Royal Academy student gold medal for his painting "The Cave of Despair."
ODNB.

Sir Moses Haim Montefiore worked as a clerk and a stockbroker before becoming president of the London Commitee of Deputies of British Jews. He was a well-known public figure in London particularly in his old age.
ODNB.

King George III was King of of Great Britain and Ireland and later the United Kingdom from 1760 to 1820, and was the grandfather of Queen Victoria.
ODNB.

Queen Charlotte was Queen of Great Britain and Ireland and later the United Kingdom from 1761 to 1818 by way of her marriage to King George III. She was entrusted with the care of the King's household and person following the Regency Act of 1811. She was well-known for her generosity and extensive book collection.
ODNB.

W. H. Cummings was a well-known English singer and music teacher. He taught at the Royal Normal School and the School for the Blind, and later became the principal of the Guildhall School of Music. Dinah's extant letters suggest that she befriended Cummings later in her life – probably in the 1870s. She considered him a very talented singer. She sent him songs in the mail, introduced him to people in her literary network, and notified him of up-and-coming musical talents.
ODNB.

Clara Cummings was married to the singer W. H. Cummings. Dinah admired Cummings and seemed to be amicable with his wife.
ODNB.

Priscilla German Reed was a famous English singer and actress. Beginning in 1854, Priscilla and her pianist husband, German Reed toured England as a travelling show called "Mr and Mrs German Reed's Entertainment." They made a living this way for most of their life, fostering talented young singers, actors, and musicians along the way. Dinah seems to have at least know of the German Reeds, though it is unclear if they had any sort of relationship.
ODNB.

Philip Abraham was father to the singer Leonora Braham. Philip Abraham lived in London and was a Professor of Hebrew. He was a prolific writer on Jewish subjects and regularly contributed to the Jewish Chronicle. He also spent some time as the Secretary for the West Jewish Synagogue of British Jews. Dinah was under the impression that he was quite poor.

Antoinette Sterling MacKinlay was a famous American contralto singer who performed regularly at important venues such as the Crystal Palace, Royal Albert Hall and Exeter Hall. She even performed before Queen Victoria in 1874. She was once a student of W. H. Cummings in London (c. 1868).
ODNB.

Helen Lemmens-Sherrington was a famous English soprano singer. She had tremendous success in England from 1860 to 1879, touring constantly as a way to support her family when her husband's work as a musician wasn't enough. In 1879, she moved to Brussels with her husband to teach singing at a conservatory.
ODNB.

Mary Louise Booth worked for Harper & Brothers publishing. She was the editor of Harper's Bazaar from 1867 until her death in 1889.
Madeleine B. Stern, "Booth, Mary Louise (Apr. 19, 1831-Mar. 5, 1889)," in Notable American Women: 1607-1950, edited by Edward T. James, Janet Wilson James, and Paul S. Boyer, Harvard UP, 1971, Web.

Louisa Parr was an English novelist who wrote a memoir of Dinah Craik for Hurst & Blackett's Women Novelists of Queen Victoria's Reign (1897). The memoir included an analytical overview of Dinah's writing, including commentary on the restraints placed on women's writers of the era.
ODNB.
Sally Mitchell, "Selected Bibliography," Dinah Mulock Craik (Boston: Twayne Publishers, 1983), 138.
The orphaned Eleanor Ogilvie is a primary character in Dinah's 1849 novel The Ogilvies.
Katharine Ogilvie is a primary character in Dinah's 1849 novel The Ogilvies.
Philip Wychnor is a primary character in Dinah's 1849 novel The Ogilvies. He is the love interest of Eleanor Ogilvie.
Leigh Pennythorne is a secondary character in Dinah's 1849 novel, The Ogilvies.
King Lear is the titular character in a Shakespearean play.
Ned Locksley is a fictional character in Mr. Chermside's novel, Ned Locksley.
Herbert Mansfield is a fictional character from The Moor Cottage by Miss Blyth.
Mabel is a fictional character from The Moor Cottage by Miss Blyth.
Millicent is a fictional character from The Moor Cottage by Miss Blyth.
Captain Jackson is a fictional character from The Moor Cottage by Miss Blyth.
Lady S. is a fictional character in Ned Locksley by Mr. Chermside.

Elisabetta was the titular character in The Story of Elisabetta Sirani – a short story that Dinah translated from Italian in 1845. The real Elisabetta Sirani was a successful Italian Baroque painter who died unexpectedly at the age of 27 in 1665. It is believed that she was poisoned by a jealous handmaiden.

Battista Zani was a central character in The Story of Elisabetta Sirani – a short story that Dinah translated from Italian in 1845. The real Battista Zani was an amateur painter who courted Elisabetta Sirani.
Arlice seems to have been one of Dinah's servants at Wildwood.
Betty was one of the three young girls to whom Dinah dedicated "How to Win Love, or Rhoda's Lesson."
Frances was one of the three young girls to whom Dinah dedicated "How to Win Love, or Rhoda's Lesson."
Jeannie was one of the three young girls to whom Dinah dedicated "How to Win Love, or Rhoda's Lesson."

David Laing was a Scottish writer, editor, and bookseller.
Chambers's Cyclopaedia of English Literature from 1830 to 1882, fourth ed., ed. Robert Carruthers, LL. D. (Edinburgh: W. & R. Chambers, 1894) 785, Web.
Willie was likely one of Dinah's servants at Wildwood.
Mrs. Linos appears to be a music instructor who helped with Dinah Craik's glee club c. 1862.
This name is noted by an unknown hand on letter PU34 in the Princeton Parrish Collection. Miss Meugius is said to be a friend of Miss Marchall's and an aspiring translator.
Dinah had a letter from Mrs. Mulock around August 1887 in which she mentions her son Francis is dead.
Kate and her sister Lily are cousins of the Pike sisters.
Lily and her sister Kate are cousins of the Pike sisters.
In one of Dinah's letters, she mentions Mrs. Homfray will give them an address to stay in Rome.
Ida was a friend of the Craiks.
Emma seems to have been a servant of Dinah's.
Miguel de Cervantes was a seventeenth-century Spanish writer.
Referred to as Aunt Eunice
Miss McDounell owned a horse that Dinah once planned to borrow.
Maggie Hooper lived in Shortlands, Kent.
Jessie was a young servant of the Craiks in the 1880s in the Corner House.
Katie was a servant of the Craiks in the 1880s.
Mrs. Dybeen was the housekeeper at Dinah Craik's cottage in Dover.
Richard Horner was Dinah's great-uncle. He was the brother of Dinah's grandmother, Maria (Horner) Mulock.
According to Dinah's aunt Alicia, Harriet Mulock was the sister of Dinah's paternal grandfather, Robert Mulock.
Mrs. Mulock was the mother of Francis Mulock.
Eliza was one of Dinah's servants.
Lady Tennyson was married to Alfred Lord Tennyson.
Sarah was the cook for the Macmillan's.
Mrs. Brown was an acquaintance of the Mulock family. She lived in London. It seems that she helped to care for Thomas Mulock Jr.'s horse, Nell, while he was at away at sea.
William Lee was married to Dinah's cousin Elizabeth (Lizzie) Reade.

persName.note:
Emma Parker was Dinah's maternal aunt. She, her husband William Parker, and their family lived at Lysways Hall near Lichfield.
Reade, The Mellards & Their Descendants, 18-20.

person.note: Mr. Watson seems to have been a business acquaintance of Ben's.

Signor Barbera also operated as an arbiter between the publishing firm Le Monnier and Italian author Manzoni over a copyright conflict in 1864.
The Literary World, James Clarke & Company, 1883.
Carlo Cesare Malvasia was an Italian writer and art historican whose works Dinah read and translated for publication by Chambers.
Bessy was one of Dinah's maids at Lynover Cottage.

Mr. Robert Anderson was a Scottish publisher who took over the firm W. Oliphant & Sons in 1858. The firm became W. Oliphant & Co. and then Oliphant, Anderson, & Ferrier. Mr. Anderson seems to have known Dinah and Noel Paton through his publishing business.
"Messrs Oliphant, Anderson & Ferrier." Publishers' Circular and Booksllers' Record of British and Foreign Literature vol. 54, no. 1304 (27 June 1891): 680-682. Web.
May Anderson lived with Dinah and Minna Lovell at Lynover Cottage.

org.note:
Edward Bentley, his son Richard and his grand-son George were three generations of publishers based out of London. The name Bentley is best-known for Richard Bentley's periodical "Bentley's Miscellany" which was edited by Charles Dickens.
Anderson, Patricia J. and Jonathan Rose, eds., "Richard Bentley," British Literary Publishing Houses, 1820-1880 106, (Detroit: Gale, 1991), 39-52. DLB 106.

Wm. S. Orr & Co was a London-based publisher run by William Somerville Orr.
ODNB.

T.C. Newby was a London publishing company run by Thomas Cautley Newby.
ODNB.
Chambers was a publishing company located in Edinburgh.
Cadell & Co was a Scottish publishing company located in Edinburgh.
Daldy Isbister & Co was a publishing company located in London.

Arthus Hall, Virtue & Co was an English publishing company founded c. 1848.
Boase, G. C., "Virtue James Sprent (1829-1892)," ODNB.
Hodgson & Graves was an English publishing company located at 6 Pall Mall, London.

John W. Parker & Son (and all its iterations) was a publishing company located in central London. From 1848, when the firm was under the direction of the younger Parker, the firm became known for embracing liberal and eventually socialist Christianity.
ODNB.

George Bell, Bell and Daldy, and George Bell and Sons were all London publishing companies owned or partially owned by George Bell.
ODNB.
Williams & Norgate were publishers with offices in London and Edinburgh. They specialized in scientific literature.
Sampson Low, Son and Company was a publishing office originally located on Fleet Street. It was founded by the well-known bookseller Sampson Low and his eldest son in 1848. ODNB.
Phillips, Sampson and Co. was a publishing firm based out of Boston. They were the founders and original publishers of the Atlantic Monthly.

Oliphant, Anderson, & Ferrier was a Scottish publishing company that was most active in the mid-late nineteenth century. They specialized in domestic fiction and biographies.
"Messrs Oliphant, Anderson & Ferrier." Publishers' Circular and Booksllers' Record of British and Foreign Literature vol. 54, no. 1304 (27 June 1891): 680-682. Web.

Griffin & Co was a Glasgow-based publishing business of Richard Griffin, John Joseph Griffin and Charles Griffin. The company sold an ecletic combination of chemicals and books.
ODNB.

The Macmillans were the family members of Daniel and Alexander Macmillan, founders of the Macmillan publishing house. For a list of the brothers' respective spouses and children, consult the ODNB entry "Macmillan Family."
The Craiks were Dinah's husband George's family.
The Singletons were friends of Dinah's while she lived at Hampstead Heath.
Dinah was very close with the Marston family throughout the 1850s and beyond. She was godmother to the family's youngest child, Philip Bourke Marston.
Dinah's paternal aunts Jane, Emily, Eliza, Frances, Ann, and Eliza Mulock lived at Bath.
The Chambers Family refers to Scottish publishers William & Robert Chambers, their wives, and their children.
The Parkers were the family of Dinah's maternal aunt Emma Parker and her husband William.
The De Morgan Family includes Professor Augustus De Morgan, the spiritualist writer and social activist Sophia De Morgan, and their seven children.
The Tomlinsons were family friends of the Mulocks.
The Jameses were the family of Dinah's close friend, Marian James.
The Ogilvies were a family that Ben and Dinah knew in Brazil.

The Stationers' Company was a Guild of Stationers in the city of London. At its conception, the Guild was comprised of those who worked in the trade of manuscript books (i.e. copiers, limners, and booksellers) but came to include printers in the early sixteenth century. The Stationers' Company owned a building in London called Stationers' Hall.
"The Hall & Heritage," The Stationers' Company, accessed Aug. 3, 2015. https://stationers.org/the-hall-heritage.html.

Ben Rhydding was a medical centre near Leeds known for its physicians' expertise in Hydro-Therapeutics. Dinah sent her brother Ben to Ben Rhydding after he had a "nervous dyspeptic attack".
"Ben Rhydding," Medical Times and Gazette Advertiser 3, no. 1124 (June 22, 1872): 181 and 246.

org.orgName: Catharine Lodge School for Young Ladies
org.note: Established in 1851, the Catharine Lodge School for Young Ladies was a boarding and day school that prepared middle-class girls to be good governesses and wives.

Established in 1264, Merton College was one of the first constituent colleges of the University of Oxford.
"The history of Merton," Merton College: Oxford, accessed July 14, 2015, http://www.merton.ox.ac.uk/about/history-merton.

Established in 1852, The Saltley Reformatory was a boy's industrial school located in central Birmingham. Its goal was to train juvenile offenders in the trades so as to mould them into productive members of society and prevent them from falling into a life of crime.
ODNB.
Barnett, Mary G. "D— The First Reformatory School Acts," Young Delinquents: A Study of Reformatory and Industrial Schools, (New York, E. P. Dutton & Co., 1913): 20-22.

The University of Oxford is the oldest university in the English speaking world. It is said to have been founded in Oxford, England the last decade of the eleventh century, c. 1096.
"Introduction and History," University of Oxford, accessed July 14, 2015, http://www.ox.ac.uk/about/organisation/history.
Fischbacher and Sandoz was a publishing firm in Paris, and also had branch houses in Neuchatel and Geneva.

org.orgName: Association for Promoting the General Welfare of the Blind
org.note: The Association for Promoting the General Welfare of the Blind was founded by Elizabeth Gilbert first as a private undertaking in 1854 and it grew into an association in 1856. Its purpose was to give blind people employment and train them in industrial occupations.

The Brothers Grimm comprised of brothers Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm. During the 1800s they collected and publsihed folklore tales. The brothers became well-known storytellers of folk tales and popularized stories such as "Cinderella", "The Frog Prince", and "Sleeping Beauty".
The Académie des Inscriptions et Belles-Lettres is a French society for the support and promotion of the humanities. It was founded in 1663.
London University was founded in 1826 as an alternative to Oxford and Cambridge. Dinah's brother Ben studied Mathematics, Latin, and Natural Philosophy at the University of London beginning in 1848.

The Royal Literary Fund is an organized scheme of assistance for writers in financial difficulty. It was established in the late eighteenth-century and is based in London.
Bradford A. Booth, "Trollope and the Royal Literary Fund," Nineteenth Century Fiction 7.3 (December 1952): 208-216, doi: 10.2307/3044361.
"About the RLF," Royal Literary Fund, https://www.rlf.org.uk/.

Phoenix was a major insurance company based in London. George Lovell was Phoenix's secretary for many years.
ODNB.
The London Joint Stock Bank was one of the first joint stock banks in London, meaning that it was owned by multiple shareholders instead of by a single private company. It operated from 1836 to 1918.
The Fields' were the family of James and Annie Fields. They lived in Boston.
The Marshalls were a family that lived in Hampstead Heath.

place.note: The Corner House was Dinah's most important residence, where she lived from 1869 until her death. It was built by the architecht Norman Shaw.
84 Addison Road is an address in Kensington, London.
Arran Cottage was a holiday home that Dinah Craik frequented in the Isle of Arran.
Bahia is a state in Eastern Brazil. Benjamin Mulock worked as a civil engineer photographing the railway in Bahia from c. 1860 to c. 1862.
Baker Street is a street in central London. Frederic Chapman and his family might have had an address on Baker Street.
Bristo Street was a street in Edinburgh where Dinah's friend Mrs. Longstaff lived. The street has since been demolished.
Bootle-cum-Linacre (Linacre) was a small hamlet located near Liverpool.
Dunblane is a small town in central Scotland.
Edinburgh is the capital city of Scotland.
Eden Cottage on Wickham Road was home to the family of Francis Miers. Eden Cottage was very short walking distance away from distance the Corner House.
Farnham is a town in Surrey, England.
33 George Square was the address of the Patons in Edinburgh.
The London office of Macmillan & Co publishing was located at 23 Henrietta Street.
The Isle of Wight is a small island off the Southern coast of England. In the nineteenth century it was a popular holiday resort for middle- and upper-class Victorians.
Kensington is a district of west-central London.
Kentish Town is a district of northwest London.
Kippenross is a geographic barony located near Dunblane, Scotland.
Lancashire is a historic county in northwestern England. In the nineteenth century, Lancashire was a major industrial centre.
Largo is a Scottish fishing village that borders the Firth of Forth.
Fife is a county of southern Scotland between the Firth of Tay and the Firth of Forth.

Liverpool is a Northwestern English city located in the historic county of Lancashire. Dinah lived in Liverpool with her brother Ben Mulock from 1858 to 1859.
Alexander, Lynn M., ed, "Dinah Mulock Craik: A Brief Chronology," John Halifax, Gentleman (Peterborough ON: Broadview, 2005), 25-27.
12 Melville Terrace is an address in Edinburgh.
Pall Mall is a street in west-central London. Hodgson & Graves had an office at 6 Pall Mall.
Piccadilly is a road in west-central London. Chapman and Hall had an office at 193 Piccadilly.
Surrey is a county in southeastern England.
The Temple Lodge is a lodging in Hammersmith, London where Dinah visited occasionally.
Torriano Avenue is a street in Kentish Town.

Upper Tooting is a district of Southern London. Alexander Macmillan of Macmillan & Co owned a spacious house in Upper Tooting where he regularly entertained and lodged friends and authors.
ODNB.
"Mr. Alexander Macmillan," Publishers Circular 58, no. 1385 (1893): 57.
Seiler, Robert M. ed., "The House of Macmillan," The Beautiful Book: Walter Pater and the House of Macmillan, (London UK: Bloomsbury, 2013), 29-35.
In the nineteenth century, Richmond was a town in northwestern Surrey, England.

Sudbrook Park was a hydropathic establishment in Richmond, Surrey. Dr. Edward Wickstead Lane took ownership of Sudbrook Park after leaving Moor Park in 1860.
Frederick Burkhardt et al., eds., The Correspondence of Charles Darwin 13 (New York: Cambridge UP, 2002): 417n7, n9.
Kate Summerscale, Mrs. Robinson's Disgrace: The Private Diary of a Victorian Woman, (New York: Bloomsbury, 2012): 60, 184.

Upper Terrace Lodge was the residence of Miss James and Miss Coates in Hampstead.
“David Gray’s First Proof-Sheet,” The Irish Monthly 15, (1887): 425.
In the nineteenth century, Amberley was a village in Sussex, England.
In the nineteenth century, Beckenham was a parish near Bromley, Kent. It was about 16 kilometres south-southeast of London.
In the nineteenth century, Bloomsbury was a district of Northwest London, just east of Camden Town.
Burton Crescent was a street in Bloomsbury, near Camden Town.
Dorset is a county in southwest England that borders the English channel.
Mabledon Place was a street in Bloomsbury, near Camden Town.
Oxford Street is a major street in west London.
Pmalder Cottage was a property in Greenock that belonged to Allan Park Paton. Dinah stayed at Pmalder Cottage in late 1850.."County Directory of Scotland (1868)," 278.

The Princess's Theatre was London's leading theatre from 1850-1859, under the management of Charles Kean. It was located in West London on Oxford Street.
M. Glen Wilson, "Kean, Charles John (1811-1868)," ODNB.
John Westland Marston had an address at 22 Rochester Road, Camden Road Villas around the year 1850.
Rose Cottage was a holiday home in Amberley that belonged to a Mr. and Mrs. Guild. Dinah stayed with the Guilds in the 1850s.

15 Sandyford Place was the residence of James and Margaret Craik in Glasgow.
